awd_titl_txt: The Interplay between Spectral and Combinatorial Properties of Graphs and Association Schemes
awd_abstract_narration:
Graph theory is essential for analyzing the structure and function of networks. Often the sizes of such networks are so large that analyzing their structures by brute force is not feasible. The challenge is to use parameters that can efficiently capture the shapes of networks. Spectral graph theory provides important tools for studying structural properties of graphs and has close connections to computer science and network design. Although the eigenvalues do not determine a graph in general, they contain important structural information that in some situations, could not be obtained by any other means. Association schemes are combinatorial and algebraic structures with high degree of regularity that sit at the core of algebraic combinatorics and have important applications in coding theory, geometry and quantum computing.  In this project, the close connections between the spectral and combinatorial properties of graphs and association schemes will be investigated. This project will involve graduate and undergraduate students at University of Delaware.
 
This project encompasses recent progress in spectral graph theory on combinatorial and spectral problems and conjectures involving simplicial rook graphs, Wenger graphs and friendship graphs as well as in the theory of association schemes by answering questions of Brouwer regarding the connectivity of strongly regular and distance-regular graphs and their subconstituents. The project will investigate conjectures of Haemers that almost all graphs are determined by their spectrum, of Godsil and Brouwer regarding the edge- and vertex-connectivity of graphs in association schemes as well as related problems such as understanding the spectral and isoperimetric properties of graphs defined by systems of equations over finite fields or graphs arising in other combinatorial problems.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the spectral and combinatorial properties of graphs and association schemes. Graphs are abstract models of networks and their study is important for both practical and theoretical purposes. They can be studied via a variety of methods including algebraic lenses involving matrices and eigenvalues and this study has led to important breakthroughs related the connectivity, expansion and reliability of networks. Association schemes are regular structures consisting of graphs on the same vertex set with regular connections between them that have important applications in computer science and coding theory among others. Their study uses tools from linear algebra, combinatorics, representation theory and geometry.

More than 15 papers have been published with the support of this grant and several others have been submitted or accepted. One Ph.D. student who graduated in 2018 was supported from this grant. This student was involved in one of the highlight results from this project: the proofs of conjectures of Karloff from 1999 and Van Dam and Sotirov from 2016 on the smallest eigenvalue of Hamming graphs and Johnson graphs. The max-cut of a network is a measure of how bipartite the graph/network is and it is an important combinatorial parameter. Many algorithms perform efficiently on bipartite graphs and it is important to have a quantitative way of assessing how far from bipartite a graph is. Determining the max-cut in general is a difficult problem and therefore, approximation algorithms are needed in this situation. In mid 1990s, Goemans and Williamson obtained an approximation algorithm with ratio 0.878 using semidefinite programming and spectral techniques. Motivated by this breakthrough work, several researchers showed that the ratio of this algorithm cannot be improved by showing that certain graphs in the Hamming and Johnson association schemes are tight examples for the Goemans-Williamson approximation algorithm. A crucial role in these results was determining the smallest eigenvalue of graphs in the Hamming and Johnson schemes and this was done in certain ranges by Karloff, Alon and Sudakov, Van Dam and Sotirov and Dumer and Kapralova. In addition, Karloff in 1999 for Johnson graphs and Van Dam and Sotirov in 2016 for Hamming graphs, made conjectures about the smallest eigenvalue for larger ranges of parameters. In joint work with Brouwer, Ihringer and the PI's Ph.D. student McGinnis, the PI proved this conjectures in 2018 and extended these results to other association schemes.

Other outcomes include results related to combinatorial version of Kac's question "Can one hear the shape of a drum ?" characterizing friendship graphs and other graphs with a small number of distinct eigenvalues. Also, the PI obtained new results related the optimal addressing of networks started by Graham and Pollak in 1970s at Bell Labs. In joint work with collaborators and his undergraduate students, the PI obtained new addressings of Hamming, Johnson, odd cycles and other graphs. The PI also determined the second eigenvalue of several Cayley graphs of the symmetric group. These graphs can be used to model communication networks and their second eigenvalue is a measure of their connectivity and reliability in information spreading.
